channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Software Developer or Matchmaker? Semi-Remote Perl Role in Manchester
item.description: Our client's mission is to connect folks in the UK and US seeking flatmates or homes to share. If you’re a Software Developer (Backend), these flatmate matchmakers want you to increase the delivery capacity of their team. With a core platform that is mostly written in Perl, you’ll work with developers to create admin tools and implement and test new site features.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer + NLP = Yes, Please! EU remote role
item.description: Our client is a global leader in machine intelligence, and they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) whiz who has experience maintaining and improving large Perl applications and tooling ecosystems. From Finland to the Faroe Islands, this remote role is open to senior Perl developers who are within two hours of Amsterdam’s time zone.

item.title: Thought-Leader Wanted. Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia (or elsewhere)
item.description: As Chief Software Architect for an international company providing online trading services,ou’ll mentor engineering teams and provide guidance in solving technical issues. In an ideal world, you’ll be on-site in Malaysia. Malta or Dubai would do in a pinch as this global company has offices there, too. However, even if you’re located outside their preferred places, they want to hear from you.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: Cross-training is important, and not only in the weight room, which is why we’re looking for a junior or intermediate Perl developer interested in cross-training Perl to Node. Our client embraces flexibility, and their ideal candidate will, too. This role is remote-friendly for those located within the UK.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They offer a fully remote position for those within two hours of London’s time zone. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites and a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 176
item.description: Cool one-liner in Raku is very impressive.

item.title: Big number, small numbers
item.description: Nice commentary using the power of Perl and Python. Well done.

item.title: Reversible Permutations
item.description: Roger sharing the power of Kotlin, very impressive. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: More funny numbers - permutable and reversible
item.description: Short and precise commentary on the weekly task. I really enjoyed it. Keep it up great work.

item.title: scrumbled numbers
item.description: Luca showing the power of Raku in this week solutions. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 176
item.description: Perl one-liner is Luis speciality. Thanks for sharing with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 176: Permuted Multiples and Reversible Numbers
item.description: Laurent continued having fun with different rogramming languages. Enough to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 176
item.description: James bonus part of the blog is not to be missed. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 176
item.description: I loved the way the code goes through improvements. Amazing, really usefull.

item.title: PWC176 - Reversible Numbers
item.description: Use of fun mathematical formula is very clever. Keep it up great work.

item.title: PWC176 - Permuted Multiples
item.description: Nice comparative solutions in Perl and Raku. Plenty to learn, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Drive It In Reverse, Then. Done.
item.description: Nice breakdown of task and then dealing with individual case. Cool work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Mixed Up and Multiplied
item.description: Fun task analysis by Colin. You will definitely enjoy this.

item.title: Magic of 142857
item.description: Congratulation on your first Raku contribution. Hope to see more in coming weeks. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Permuted Reversibles
item.description: Plenty of different approach being discussed and shared. Well done. Thanks for sharing as always.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 176
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Permuted Multiples" and "Reversible Numbers" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 177
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Damm Algorithm" and "Palindromic Prime Cyclops Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Testing Code That is Difficult to Test (With Perl)
item.description: A very interesting aspect of testing discussed here. Highly recommended if you are into testing.

item.title: More Things I Should Have Already Figured Out Years Ago
item.description: Are you Mojo fan? If yes then you should check out this.

item.title: Match Anything, Quickly
item.description: Interesting benchmark when it comes to filter using regex objects or sub wrapping a match.

item.title: SPVM continues to undergo heavy changes.
item.description: Yuki sharing recent changes to SPVM in a nutshell.

item.title: MooseX::Extended
item.description: Curtis announced proper try/catch support in the latest release of MooseX::Extended. Please give it a try.

item.title: #576 - Perl is on the Rise?
item.description:
Hi there,

Personally I have noticed the fresh energy among all Perl fans ever since the release of latest Perl v5.36. I am telling this based on the amount of positive noise I heard on various public platform. There are still few in the pipeline that would give further push e.g. Corinna. If you are interested to know more then please do checkout this page maintained by Curtis Poe.

MetaCPAN is another place where you can see all the latest cool Perl projects. I know plenty of volunteers helping to improve the code base. If you use a distribution and you like it then why not share your experience with the Perl Community and submit your proposal to Perl Advent Calendar 2022? Or if you have created one then why not share with rest of the world.

If you are new to Perl and needs help then please do give us a shout. There are plenty of help available on various public platforms.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
